I am the rose<S>2261</S> of Sharon<S>8289</S>, and the lily<S>7799</S> of the valleys<S>6010</S>.
As the lily<S>7799</S> among thorns<S>2336</S>, so is my love<S>7474</S> among the daughters<S>1323</S>.
As the apple tree<S>8598</S> among the trees<S>6086</S> of the wood<S>3293</S>, so is my beloved<S>1730</S> among the sons<S>1121</S>. I sat<S>3427</S> down under his shadow<S>6738</S> with great delight<S>2530</S>, and his fruit<S>6529</S> was sweet<S>4966</S> to my taste<S>2441</S>. <sup>I sat: Heb. I delighted and sat down, etc</sup> <sup>taste: Heb. palate</sup>
He brought<S>935</S> me to the banqueting<S>3196</S> house<S>1004</S>, and his banner<S>1714</S> over me was love<S>160</S>. <sup>banqueting: Heb. house of wine</sup>
Stay<S>5564</S> me with flagons<S>809</S>, comfort<S>7502</S> me with apples<S>8598</S>: for I am sick<S>2470</S> of love<S>160</S>. <sup>comfort: Heb. straw me with apples</sup>
His left hand<S>8040</S> is under my head<S>7218</S>, and his right hand<S>3225</S> doth embrace<S>2263</S> me.
I charge<S>7650</S> you, O ye daughters<S>1323</S> of Jerusalem<S>3389</S>, by the roes<S>6643</S>, and<S>176</S> by the hinds<S>355</S> of the field<S>7704</S>, that ye stir not up<S>5782</S>, nor awake<S>5782</S> my love<S>160</S>, till he please<S>2654</S>. <sup>I charge: Heb. I adjure you</sup>
The voice<S>6963</S> of my beloved<S>1730</S>! behold, he cometh<S>935</S> leaping<S>1801</S> upon the mountains<S>2022</S>, skipping<S>7092</S> upon the hills<S>1389</S>.
My beloved<S>1730</S> is like<S>1819</S> a roe<S>6643</S> or a young<S>6082</S> hart<S>354</S>: behold, he standeth<S>5975</S> behind<S>310</S> our wall<S>3796</S>, he looketh forth<S>7688</S> at the windows<S>2474</S>, shewing<S>6692</S> himself through the lattice<S>2762</S>. <sup>shewing: Heb. flourishing</sup>
My beloved<S>1730</S> spake<S>6030</S>, and said<S>559</S> unto me, Rise up<S>6965</S>, my love<S>7474</S>, my fair one<S>3303</S>, and come away<S>3212</S>.
For, lo, the winter<S>5638</S> is past<S>5674</S>, the rain<S>1653</S> is over<S>2498</S> and gone<S>1980</S>;
The flowers<S>5339</S> appear<S>7200</S> on the earth<S>776</S>; the time<S>6256</S> of the singing<S>2158</S> of birds is come<S>5060</S>, and the voice<S>6963</S> of the turtle<S>8449</S> is heard<S>8085</S> in our land<S>776</S>;
The fig tree<S>8384</S> putteth forth<S>2590</S> her green figs<S>6291</S>, and the vines<S>1612</S> with the tender grape<S>5563</S> give<S>5414</S> a good smell<S>7381</S>. Arise<S>6965</S>, my love<S>7474</S>, my fair one<S>3303</S>, and come away<S>3212</S>.
O my dove<S>3123</S>, that art in the clefts<S>2288</S> of the rock<S>5553</S>, in the secret<S>5643</S> places of the stairs<S>4095</S>, let me see<S>7200</S> thy countenance<S>4758</S>, let me hear<S>8085</S> thy voice<S>6963</S>; for sweet<S>6156</S> is thy voice<S>6963</S>, and thy countenance<S>4758</S> is comely<S>5000</S>.
Take<S>270</S> us the foxes<S>7776</S>, the little<S>6996</S> foxes<S>7776</S>, that spoil<S>2254</S> the vines<S>3754</S>: for our vines<S>3754</S> have tender grapes<S>5563</S>.
My beloved<S>1730</S> is mine, and I am his: he feedeth<S>7462</S> among the lilies<S>7799</S>.
Until the day<S>3117</S> break<S>6315</S>, and the shadows<S>6752</S> flee away<S>5127</S>, turn<S>5437</S>, my beloved<S>1730</S>, and be thou like<S>1819</S> a roe<S>6643</S> or a young<S>6082</S> hart<S>354</S> upon the mountains<S>2022</S> of Bether<S>1336</S>. <sup>of Bether: or, of division</sup>
